name: Kepler-265
scenarioDescription:
The Kepler-265 Exoplanetary System

Kepler-265 is a star with 1.097 times the mass of the Sun, and 1.1 times its radius. It is located 4332.04 light years away from the solar system.

Kepler-265 is known to have 4 exoplanets in orbit around it.

Kepler-265 b

Kepler-265 b was discovered by the Kepler observatory using the transit method. Its discovery was announced in 2014-03. Its semi-major axis is 0.07 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. It takes 6.85 Earth days to complete an orbit around its host star, Kepler-265.

The mass of Kepler-265 b is 4.27 times the mass of Earth. The radius of Kepler-265 b is 1.86 that of Earth. At 4.27 Earth masses, Kepler-265 b is a so called Super Earth. Super Earths could be terrestrial worlds like Earth, but they could also be ocean worlds or terrestrial worlds wrapped in a substantial atmosphere, in which case some refer to them as Mini Neptunes. No Super Earths are known to exist in our solar system, but if it exists, the so-called Planet Nine could very well be a super Earth, as it is hypothesized to have a mass between five and ten Earth masses.

Kepler-265 c

Kepler-265 c was discovered by the Kepler observatory using the transit method. Its discovery was announced in 2014-03. Its semi-major axis is 0.13 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. It takes 17.03 Earth days to complete an orbit around its host star, Kepler-265.

The mass of Kepler-265 c is 9.83 times the mass of Earth. The radius of Kepler-265 c is 2.63 that of Earth. At 9.83 Earth masses, Kepler-265 c is a so called Super Earth. Super Earths could be terrestrial worlds like Earth, but they could also be ocean worlds or terrestrial worlds wrapped in a substantial atmosphere, in which case some refer to them as Mini Neptunes. No Super Earths are known to exist in our solar system, but if it exists, the so-called Planet Nine could very well be a super Earth, as it is hypothesized to have a mass between five and ten Earth masses.

No Super Earths are known to exist in our solar system, but if it exists, the so-called Planet Nine could very well be a super Earth, as it is hypothesized to have a mass between five and ten Earth masses.

description: 3D visualisation and gravity simulation of the exoplanet system Kepler-265, which contains 4 planets and was discovered by Kepler.
